Something I wish more scifi content acknowledged
Almost every single major scifi film / series has rear thrusters and rear thrusters ONLY
That... that's not how space works...
Yeah, a lot of scifi treats space flight the same as flight in air
It's really cool when these details are added in
you just make special wings that can press against a vacuum to provide friction to rotate and spin!
I do wonder what actual spacecraft will be like, though
Yes, we have space shuttles, but those are designed specifically with re-entering the atmosphere in mind
What if we want spacecraft not only capable of operating in space, but being able to shift to flight in the atmosphere?
so long as they are efficient and structurally sound we can make em look like anytthing-
On that note, what would fighter craft look like if they're primarily designed for combat?
And the Lunar Lander is also more purpose built :P
Though it does seem to be the closest we've gotten to a generalist spacecraft design.
future space flight is gonna be boring in terms of design because just about everything would probably be best as a sphere XD
Interstellar probably has the most realistic spacecraft design I've seen.
Passengers, mixed up my films xD
You could have rocks or other debris flying through at a fraction of the speed of light
fortunately for that space is very low density.
even the asteroid belt is pretty much just empty space

You'd never see them coming, and you probably couldn't react in time.  How do you protect against something like that, or prepare a ship in the event that one of these things rips a hole clear through the ship.
thats right you want to invate earth with a GIANT army of spaceships? good luck getting to us in one piece!
I should see what the science behind that shield in Passengers was
You know, that energy field design specifically to deflect / destroy oncoming rocks to protect the ship?  But one still got through and was the catalyst for the plot? xD
I have not seen that movie
If you like Chris Pratt / Jennifer Lawrence, they both have a fantastic performance.

Maybe not the best, but odds are good that you will enjoy watching it
Tbh, over time there's become a bit of a disconnect between critics and audiences.
Not saying there aren't films that are universally loved by critics and audiences, but it's becoming more and more common for there to be films that critics love, and audiences hate, and vice-versa.
critics are a lot more critical. it's like it is in the name
Ord, did you want a rough plot synopsys?
nah, I can look it up
I'm not saying that critics aren't critical.  I'm saying that what critics like and what audiences like has diverged.
7/10 is a pretty meh audience score. not bad, but not great

But it was interesting to watch people lose it in spaaaaaaaaaaace
but if it's got good visuals and is a harder scifi, can be worth a watch for that
So, The Witch is one of those films where I mention a bit of a disconnect
90% approval by critics, but 59% by audiences
